across.text: Youngster initially enthused by Indonesian climber
across.explanation: CUBEB(i.e. “Indonesian climber” – Chambers offers this: “the dried berry ofPiper cubeba, an Indonesian climbing pepper shrub, formerly used as a drug to treat infections of the urinary tract”). Solution is CUB (i.e. “youngster”) followed by E and B (i.e. “initially enthused by”, i.e. the first letters of “enthused” and “by”). Made-to-fit rubbish.

across.text: Struck, holding wife inside animal shelter
across.explanation: COWSHED(i.e. “animal shelter”). Solution is COSHED (i.e. “struck”) wrapped around or “holding” W (a recognised abbreviation of “wife”), like so: CO(W)SHED.

across.text: Stew made by shy Liverpudlian
across.explanation: LOBSCOUSE(i.e. “stew” – and again to Chambers: “a stew or hash with vegetables or biscuit, a sea dish”). Solution is LOB (i.e. “shy” or throw) followed by SCOUSE (i.e. “Liverpudlian”). Never heard of it.

across.text: Book of words governor’s kept in house
across.explanation: THESAURUS(i.e. “book of words”). Solution is HE’S (i.e. “governor’s”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of His Excellency, if you go in for all that bowing and scraping) placed “in” TAURUS (i.e. “house” or sign of the zodiac), like so: T(HE’S)AURUS.

across.text: Where courses may be provided along certain lines
across.explanation: RESTAURANT CAR. Clue plays on railway “lines” and a train carriage in which food is served. That’s about it, I guess.

across.text: Owns gallery shaped like a spear
across.explanation: HASTATE(i.e. “shaped like a spear”). Solution is HAS (i.e. “owns”) followed by TATE (i.e. an art “gallery” in London). A new one on me. Apparently from the Latinhasta, meaning spear.

across.text: British soldiers given pay for preparing drinks
across.explanation: BREWAGE(i.e. “preparing drinks”). Solution is B (a recognised abbreviation of “British”) followed by RE (i.e. “soldiers”, specifically the Royal Engineers of the British Army) and WAGE (i.e. “pay”).

across.text: Happiest, surprisingly, when son leaves grave message
across.explanation: EPITAPH(i.e. “grave message”, or tombstone inscription). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “surprisingly” of HAPPIEST once the S has been removed (indicated by “when son leaves” – S being a recognised abbreviation of “son”).

across.text: Face a hard task? As a popular journalist one might
across.explanation: HAVE ONE’S WORK CUT OUT. Solution satisfies “face a hard task” and “as a popular journalist one might”, referring to press cuttings.

across.text: Tyneside graduate goes west? So be it
across.explanation: AMEN(i.e. “so be it”). Solution is NE (i.e. “Tyneside”, or the North-East of England) and MA (i.e. “graduate”, specifically a Master of Arts) all reversed (indicated by “goes west” – this being an across clue), like so: AM-EN.

across.text: Sailor originally involved in Beds town’s cleaning process
across.explanation: ABLUTIONS(i.e. “cleaning process”). Solution is AB (i.e. “sailor”, specifically one of Able-Bodied rank) followed by I (i.e. “originally involved”, i.e. the first letter of “involved”) once placed “in” LUTON’S (i.e. “Beds town’s”), like so: AB-LUT(I)ON’S.

across.text: Extend downward dimension of enclosure by river
across.explanation: DEEPEN(i.e. “extend downward dimension”). Solution is PEN (i.e. “enclosure”) placed after or “by” DEE (i.e. “river”), like so: DEE-PEN.

across.text: Medic swallowed by big fish in Arctic territory
across.explanation: TUNDRA(i.e. “Arctic territory”). Solution is DR (i.e. “medic”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of “doctor”) placed in or “swallowed by” TUNA (i.e. “big fish”), like so: TUN(DR)A.

across.text: Broken hearts originally haunting a ruler of great importance
across.explanation: EARTHSHAKING(i.e. “of great importance”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “broken”) of HEARTS followed by H (i.e. “originally haunting”, i.e. the first letter of “haunting”), then A and KING (i.e. “ruler”), like so: EARTHS-H-A-KING.

across.text: Final Greek poet beheaded in confines of bare cell
across.explanation: BLASTOMERE(i.e. “cell” – and to Chambers once more: “one of the cells formed in an early stage of the cleavage of a fertilized ovum”. Another everyday word, then). Solution is LAST (i.e. “final”) and HOMER (i.e. “Greek poet”) once its first letter has been removed (indicated by “beheaded”) all placed “in” BE (i.e. “confines of bare”, i.e. the first and last letters of “bare”), like so: B(LAST-OMER)E.

across.text: Give excessive work to old priest returning cross
across.explanation: OVERBURDEN(i.e. “give excessive work to”). Solution is O (a recognised abbreviation of “old”) followed by REV (i.e. “priest”, in this case a shortened form of “reverend”) reversed (indicated by “returning”), then BURDEN (i.e. “cross”, as in one’s cross to bear), like so: O-VER-BURDEN.

across.text: Endless moral rectitude concerning ship’s owner
across.explanation: PROPRIETRESS(i.e. “owner”). Solution is PROPRIETY (i.e. “moral rectitude”) with its last letter removed (indicated by “endless”) and the remainder followed by RE (i.e. “concerning” – think email replies) and SS (i.e. “ship”, a recognised abbreviation of a steamship), like so: PROPRIET-RE-SS.

across.text: Partner finally secures employment on European river
across.explanation: SPOUSE(i.e. “partner”). Solution is S (i.e. “finally secures”, i.e. the last letter of “secures”) followed by USE (i.e. “employment”) once it has first been placed “on” or after PO (a “river” in Italy), like so: S-(PO)-USE.

across.text: Property in East, say
across.explanation: ESTATE(i.e. “property”). Solution is E (a recognised abbreviation of “east”) followed by STATE (i.e. “say”).

across.text: European prince, carrying cape, left social venue
across.explanation: DANCEHALL(i.e. “social venue”). Solution is DANE (i.e. “European”) and HAL (i.e. “prince” – a reference to Shakespeare’s portrayal of a young King Henry V. This is a useful one to keep in mind because short obscure word + Shakespeare reference = catnip for cryptic crossword setters) all wrapped around or “carrying” C (a recognised abbreviation of “cape”, the geographic feature). This is all then followed by L (a recognised abbreviation of “left”), like so: (DAN(C)E-HAL)-L

across.text: Relax, having letters read aloud
across.explanation: EASE. Solution satisfies “relax” and “having letters read aloud”, in this case a homophone of plural E.

across.text: Part of US which briefly employs leaders in Denver, Colorado
across.explanation: DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA(i.e. “part of US”, these days better known as Washington D.C.). The remainder of the clue plays on how the initials D.C. are also the “leaders in Denver, Colorado”, or the first letters of “Denver” and “Colorado”.

across.text: Reportedly regret dig in simulated conversation
across.explanation: RHUBARB(i.e. “simulated conversation”, referring to a word extras mutter in the background of film or TV scenes in lieu of actual conversation). Solution is a homophone (indicated by “reportedly”) of RUE (i.e. “regret”) followed by BARB (i.e. “dig” or criticism), like so: RHU-BARB.

across.text: Verse in ancient language also inspiring a NE European
across.explanation: LATVIAN(i.e. “NE European”). Solution is V (a recognised abbreviation of “verse”) placed “in” LATIN (i.e. “ancient language”) along with, separately, (indicated by “also inspiring”) A, like so: LAT(V)I(A)N.

across.text: Officers with notices, in French to begin with
across.explanation: ENSIGNS(i.e. army “officers”). Solution is SIGNS (i.e. “notices”) with EN (i.e. “in French”, i.e. the French for “in”) placed “to begin with”, like so: EN-SIGNS.

across.text: French writer, chap with castle at end of wood
across.explanation: François-René deCHATEAUBRIAND(i.e. “French writer”). Solution is BRIAN (i.e. “chap’s” name) placed after or “with” CHATEAU (i.e. “castle”) and followed by D (i.e. “end of wood”, i.e. the last letter of “wood”), like so: CHATEAU-BRIAN-D. Never heard of him, nor anything in his oeuvre, but I guess it helps the setter meet the minimum French quota this week. Wait, did I say “oeuvre” just then in my withering dig at the Frenchness of Jumbos? Zut alors! L’ironie…

across.text: Plotter, one who fascinates?
across.explanation: INTRIGUER. Solution satisfies “plotter” and “one who fascinates”.

across.text: Modern way to dip into coffee? Certainly
across.explanation: LATTER-DAY(i.e. “modern”). Solution is RD (i.e. “way”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of a “road”) placed “into” LATTE (i.e. “coffee”) and AY (i.e. “certainly”, poetically), like so: LATTE-(RD)-AY.

across.text: US city taking ages to accept a British monarch
across.explanation: YONKERS(i.e. “US city” in New York State). Solution is YONKS (i.e. “ages”) wrapped around or “accepting” ER (i.e. “a British monarch”, specifically Elizabeth Regina), like so: YONK(ER)S.

across.text: Perceived as only a subsidiary journalist?
across.explanation: NOTED(i.e. “perceived”). When written as NOT ED the solution playfully satisfies “only a subsidiary journalist”, i.e. not the editor.

down.text: Net wears thin, we hear? It’s something often delivered
down.explanation: CATCHPHRASE(i.e. a saying that’s “often delivered”). Solution is CATCH (i.e. to “net”) followed by a homophone (indicated by “we hear”) of FRAYS (i.e. “wears thin”).

down.text: Consecrate land originally held by good queen
down.explanation: BLESS(i.e. “consecrate”). Solution is L (i.e. “land originally”, i.e. the first letter of “land”) placed in or “held by” BESS (i.e. “good queen”, Good Queen Bess being a byname of Elizabeth I, apparently), like so: B(L)ESS.

down.text: Prevaricate, but attend a fight over the Aussie outback
down.explanation: BEAT ABOUT THE BUSH(i.e. “prevaricate”). Solution is BE AT A BOUT (i.e. “attend a fight”) followed by THE BUSH (i.e. “Aussie outback”).

down.text: Funeral procession my sheep ultimately impede
down.explanation: CORTEGE(i.e. “funeral procession”). Solution is COR (i.e. “my”, both exclamations) followed by TEG (a “sheep” in its second year, apparently) and E (i.e. “ultimately impede”, i.e. the last letter of “impede”).

down.text: Used to be game, installing hotel’s facilities for 23
down.explanation: WASHBOWLS(i.e. “facilities for 23” – the solution to 23a being ABLUTIONS). Solution is WAS (i.e. “used to be”) and BOWLS (i.e. “game”) all wrapped around or “installing” H (“hotel” in the phonetic alphabet), like so: WAS-(H)-BOWLS.

down.text: Hard bargaining involving Arabs and Andalusians, perhaps?
down.explanation: HORSE-TRADING(i.e. “hard bargaining”). Clue plays on “Arabs” and “Andalusians” being breeds of horses. The latter is also a chicken, so make sure you’ve got the correct riding gear before mounting one.

down.text: Underworld boss having quick fix is bumped off
down.explanation: DISPATCHED(i.e. “bumped off”). Solution is DIS (i.e. “underworld boss”, also known as Pluto. Another useful one to keep in mind because short obscure word + classics reference = Viagra for cryptic crossword setters. Well, the male ones anyway…) followed by PATCHED (i.e. “having quick fix”).

down.text: Give up holiday
down.explanation: LEAVE. Solution satisfies “give up” and “holiday”.

down.text: Pub sign covering live outdoor meal
down.explanation: BARBECUE(i.e. “outdoor meal”). Solution is BAR (i.e. “pub”) and CUE (i.e. “sign”, theatrically speaking) all wrapped around or “covering” BE (i.e. “live”), like so: BAR-(BE)-CUE.

down.text: Plain as peel may be, releasing energy
down.explanation: CANDID(i.e. “plain”). Solution is CANDIED (i.e. “as peel may be”) once the E has been removed (indicated by “releasing energy” – E being a recognised abbreviation of “energy”).

down.text: Object taken in by pawnbroker, note, awaiting applicant
down.explanation: UNCLAIMED(i.e. “awaiting applicant”). Solution is AIM (i.e. “object”) placed “in” UNCLE (slang for a “pawnbroker”) and D (a musical “note”), like so: UNCL(AIM)E-D.

down.text: Turbulent weather near pottery
down.explanation: EARTHENWARE(i.e. “pottery”). “Turbulent” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of WEATHER NEAR.

down.text: Woman heading for vessel on a large lake
down.explanation: VALERIE(i.e. “woman’s” name). Solution is V (i.e. “heading for vessel”, i.e. the first letter of “vessel”) followed by A, then L (a recognised abbreviation of “lake”) and ERIE (one of the Great “Lakes” of North America).

down.text: Part of pedal pilot used going north round City
down.explanation: TOECLIP(i.e. “part of [bicycle] pedal” designed to keep the foot in place). Solution is PILOT reversed (indicated by “going north” – this being a down clue) and wrapped “round” EC (i.e. “city”, basically the postcode area for the City of London. Another useful one to keep in mind for future as obscure short word + London reference = cocaine for Jumbo setters, given The Times is predominantly a London newspaper), like so: TO(EC)LIP.

down.text: Impossible? Not in the search I mount regularly
down.explanation: OUT OF THE QUESTION(i.e. “impossible”). Solution is OUT OF (i.e. “not in”) followed by THE, then QUEST (i.e. “search”), then I and ON (i.e. “mount regularly”, i.e. every other letter of MOUNT).

down.text: Neat woman’s daughter, an animal minder
down.explanation: OXHERD(i.e. “animal minder”). Solution is OX (i.e. “neat”, a variant meaning of the word is an archaic term for livestock) followed by HER (i.e. “woman’s”) and D (a recognised abbreviation of “daughter”).

down.text: A function for the speaker to fix
down.explanation: ASSIGN(i.e. “to fix”). Solution is A followed by a homophone (indicated by “for the speaker”) of SINE (i.e. a trigonometric “function”).

down.text: Joints English rejected, laid for foreign parliament
down.explanation: KNESSET(i.e. “foreign parliament”, specifically of Israel). Solution is KNEES (i.e. “joints”) with one of the Es removed (indicated by “English rejected” – E being a recognised abbreviation of “English”) and the remainder followed by SET (i.e. “laid”), like so: KNES-SET.

down.text: Prize possession we associated with English essayist
down.explanation: EWE-LAMB(i.e. “prize possession” of a pauper, apparently a Biblical reference). Solution is WE placed after or “associated with” E (a recognised abbreviation of “English”) and followed by Charles LAMB (i.e. “essayist”), like so: E-(WE)-LAMB.

down.text: Fisherman’s club freed study dominated by ministers
down.explanation: PRIEST-RIDDEN(i.e. “dominated by ministers”). Solution is PRIEST (i.e. “fisherman’s club” or mallet for killing fish – a new one on me, but interesting) followed by RID (i.e. “freed”) and DEN (i.e. “study”).

down.text: Like the treatment of those expecting somehow to steal crib
down.explanation: OBSTETRICAL(i.e. “like the treatment of those expecting” babies). “Somehow” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of TO STEAL CRIB.

down.text: Confident lasses Freud mismanaged
down.explanation: SELF-ASSURED(i.e. “confident”). “Mismanaged” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of LASSES FREUD.

down.text: Wise men initially supporting female law administrators collectively
down.explanation: MAGISTRACY(i.e. “law administrators collectively”). Solution is MAGI (i.e. “wise men”) followed by S (i.e. “initially supporting”, i.e. the first letter of “supporting”) and TRACY (i.e. “female’s” name).

down.text: Alumni blunt about an opposer of enlightenment
down.explanation: OBSCURANT(i.e. “opposer of enlightenment”). Solution is OBS (i.e. “alumni”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of Old Boy made plural) followed by CURT (i.e. “blunt”) once wrapped “about” AN, like so: OBS-CUR(AN)T.

down.text: Protective of duck crossing eastern marshes
down.explanation: DEFENSIVE(i.e. “protective”). Solution is DIVE (i.e. “duck”) wrapped around or “crossing” E (a recognised abbreviation of “eastern”) and FENS (i.e. “marshes”), like so: D(E-FENS)IVE.

down.text: Detectives certain to be removed from cover
down.explanation: DISBOUND(i.e. “removed from cover” in relation to books – not a word explicitly supported by Chambers but Oxford backs it up). Solution is DIS (i.e. “detectives”, specifically Detective Inspectors) followed by BOUND (i.e. “certain”, as in “bound to be” some outcome).

down.text: Mycenaean prince of old relaxes, conserving energy
down.explanation: ORESTES(i.e. “Mycenaean prince” of Greek mythology, son of Agamemnon). Solution is O (a recognised abbreviation of “old”) followed by RESTS (i.e. “relaxes”) once wrapped around or “conserving” E (a recognised abbreviation of “energy”), like so: O-REST(E)S.

down.text: Flower cluster European male kept in stock
down.explanation: RACEME(i.e. “flower cluster” – and to Chambers once more: “an inflorescence in which stalked flowers are borne in acropetal succession on a main stalk or lateral branches”. Glad that’s been cleared up, then). Solution is E (a recognised abbreviation of “European”) and M (ditto “male”) both placed “in” RACE (i.e. “stock” – Chambers supports it, albeit deep into its definitions), like so: RAC(E-M)E.

down.text: Truck, possibly, taking parrot across river
down.explanation: LORRY(i.e. “truck”). Solution is LORY (a kind of “parrot”) wrapped around or placed “across” R (a recognised abbreviation of “river”), like so: LO(R)RY.

down.text: Scrawny relative holding up beginning of game
down.explanation: GAUNT(i.e. “scrawny”). Solution is AUNT (i.e. “relative”) placed after or “holding up” G (i.e. “beginning [letter] of game”), like so: G-AUNT.
